reviews.review_msg: Possess good level of Charisma, especially in person. Knows his stuff well and open to answer field/industry related questions. The group work is very important for a good grade. Be prepared to choose a passionate project to pursue and he will help you out. Be participative in class and make him remember your face for a good participation grade.

This class is just dependent on the group project. Quizzes and final is easy. The things he chose to deduct for sometimes seems random. Lectures were so boring. Ulrich doesn't have much personality to him which makes it hard to be engaged especially for an online class. Also, participation marks seems arbitrary.

If you just want to pass, take 361 with him. You can get 100% on all project components by simply filling out his provided template with content relevant to your project. But I think it'd be tough to aim for A or A+ in this course as his MCQ for the final and the 5 quizzes are so vague (seems like there's more than 1 right answer where it shouldnt'

Group project heavy class so get in a group project and class itself is not hard. Some items were marked quite late and the prof didn't really answer questions well. He's obviously experienced as a PM but this doesn't translate to being a good professor. Nothing wrong with taking 361 with him, but nothing great.

Lectures were dry. Participation is graded weekly. Final Exam and Quizzes were all MC. Group project IS VERY IMPORTANT and will be worth about half your grade (consists of weekly assignments and final report). Expect to spend 2-3 hours each week with your group. No midterm and overall an easy course if you are on top of each assignment.
One of the best prof!

He is a very insightful and good prof. You get to choose your own groups and what you want to do for the project, which is awesome. Make sure to participate in class and study the weekly online quizzes for the final exam!

This was my last course at SFU, and it was honestly the best. Very happy to round out my degree with this very practical course. Loved the applicability of the concepts to my career, and really appreciated the depth of industry knowledge Ulrich brought to class. Applying what you learned in the class project worked well, and rubrics were detailed a

Sometimes there would be mistakes in his lecture slides and the class had to point out what was wrong with the material for him to actually realize. Quizes are easy as long as you read the textbook and final exam is super easy. However, your participation grade was complete garbage because of his ambiguous way of assessing your class participation.

Stutters / disorganized, but regardless is passionate lecturer and wants you to do well. Participation every class separates you from the pack. Being creative, choosing good group members, and meeting deadlines is also key. Final was 75 MC and fair, but a high mark requires comprehensive lecture slide review.

Ulrich is really nice and he really knows what hes talking about! The group project and final were easy so the averages were very high. Participation was the main factor that separated the A students from the B students

The professor is nice. He is knowledgeable with respect to the course material. Participation makes a big chunk of this course, so try and participate in every class. Same thing goes for weekly quizzes. 40% of the grade is group based, so try and get a good group. There are no surprises in the final exam, difficulty level more or less as the quiz.

Pay attention on the participation especially first two classes. He will remember you later on, the participation mark weight even adjusted by him when he grade. The presentation grade is tricky, though it is only take 5% mark. No actual time limit and ppt page limit. He said 10mins but no group met. Talk to prof after class, you never know he want

Ulrich is the best instructor I have ever met, in many years at SFU. He is not only very insightful, but also witty and easy going - makes university fun and educational. Hi know-how from the lock and security camera industries really add a lot of relevance to the course. I wish they made him a permanent faculty member!!!
He is a sincerely nice guy. I enjoy the way he teaches and you will too.

Dr. Paschen is a great professor. He encourages questions and doesn't try to trick you in his quizzes or exams. Participation is a must (you really get what you put in to the course) and attendance is also mandatory because his quizzes make up a big chunk of grades. Make sure to do the chapter reading and see him during office hours for extra help.

Ulrich is a very diligent professor. Asks what was not clear and discusses the topic again at the beginning of the next lecture. The class was engaging, and he brought in current project managers to share their experiences, which was great.

Really engaging class. Lectures are intersting enough to stay awake even in a 5:30 class. Lots of real-life examples from Ulrichs career help illustrate project management well. Ended up being one of the most fun, but definitely also the most work classes. Got to choose our own group and project, so it is what you make of that. Would take again!
It was her first time teaching and it was rough. The exam was long and sufficient time was not given as many did not finish. Attention to detail could use some work.

Please take this class with any other professor other than Connie. Don't bother with the textbook (slides are 60 pages). Participation is in the course outline but she makes it hard for you to contribute and she doesn't even know your name so there's no way to track. Unclear assignment rubrics, no support, and VERY rude with presentations. AVOID!!!

Connie gets unnecessary hate in my opinion. For BUS 361 I think she did a solid job. Class was primarily for lecture and she gave time to groups to work on the group project. Her criteria can be slightly unclear at times, but often she will clarify criteria details during lecture. She met with teams to deliver feedback, which I really liked.

Probably one of the worst classes I've taken at SFU. This course is based on project management, however, she has awful communication and this class is so disorganized. I'm not quite sure how she is qualified to teach this course tbh. Goes off topic during lectures and they are extremely dry. Hopefully she can improve how she structures the course.

You learn a lot about project management and actually run your own fundraiser in this class. It was a rewarding, useful experience. That said, the time required for this class is 2-3x as much as a regular class. For example, your group is expected to meet 5 times a week. If you have the time, and are willing to put in the work, take this class

This prof is really supportive of his students. Work hard and you will be fine. Pretty fair amount of work, but that final was ridiculous. Tested on details that you would never assume we're important.

One of my favourite classes by far. If you put the effort into the project and create something you are proud to do it will be easy to work hard towards your goals. Your project does not have to succeed but do find something unique and different and you will get a great mark for it  Exam was somewhat hard but fair at the same time.

This class was challenging and rewarding.  He expects hard work but it makes it that much more rewarding to try hard in his class.  He doesn't expect project to succeed, he actually expects it to fail - don't worry if you didn't meet your measures as well as you wanted to.  Study slides and look over textbk for final exam. Know EVM & critical path

Kamal is an excellent lecturer; however, the course involves a heavy workload. The assignments are very long and must be completed within tight deadlines. The project, nontheless, was a great challenge and was extremely rewarding. The final exam was difficult (no surprises as it "normalizes" the curve).

Kamal tries very hard to portray himself as someone knowledgeable in the MIS field, but seasoned students can tell his teaching style and his experience with IT is old school and dated. At times, he sounded condescending. He is responsive when you contact him. The course material is very useful for MIS students. Expect a significant amount of work.

WOULD NOT RECOMMEND. He seems like a nice guy but after suffering through the entire semester I have no more empathy for him. 45% of your grade is based on your group project but he REFUSES to do peer evaluations. Lectures are completely useless and since theres no midterm, the final is on all 14 chapters which you have to teach to yourself.

Michael is really nice and helpful, but classes were not useful and participation matters. Group work is 45% of your mark, with 2 presentations and 2 large papers. Final based on the ENTIRE textbook. Everything is marked on a difficult, unclear scale. If you really want to learn, do not take his class.

Michael is a nice guy but the worst prof I have ever had. Lectures were useless discussion that didn't relate to the course material . His marking is very subjective and provides grades back extremely late. The final wasn't hard but was challenging because the entire class had to learn everything from the textbook in a week cause he taught nothing.
Lectures are useless, can't learn much from him. Grades harshly on assignments and not really a flexible person

Landon is a great professor. His lectures are both informative and interesting. He puts information in a way that is easily relatable and appealing. He does have issues with organization, but it's not that big of a deal. Overall, he's a great prof that's open to feedback and is always willing to listen to your needs.

I dont quite know what happened in the earlier courses, but I had a great experience (Summer 2017). Patient and engaging instructor, really good application of the learnings in the project. Quizzes were not too hard, downright easy if you had done your readings. Make sure to create the video for 2% of bonus grade at the end.

I took 361 with her in the summer term, and my experience was quite different from what others have been sayin here. Respectful, accessible outside of class, fair marking, interesting real-life examples. There was no TA, so she did all the marking herself. Learned relevant stuff for my professional career.

Lectures were pointless. The only reason you should go to class is to get participation marks.   Semester long group project was ironically poorly planned and expectations were vague throughout. You were able to choose your group which is nice if you take the course with friends. SOL if you didn't.  I do not feel ready to take the CAPM exam.

Boring lectures, vague criteria, lazily written final.  Group project was based entirely on documentation, not success of project. Some groups had 3 people show up to their event, other offerings usually base grades on measurements achieved.  Exam 30 min, just memorization of random stuff on the slides eg How many areas are in the PMBOK? - really?

Nice to talk to, but lectures were boring. Expectations for assignments which make up the majority of your grade were very unclear. Show up to class for quizzes but other than that lectures were useless. I do not recommend taking any classes with her.

Probably the worst prof I've taken a class with at Beedie in the past 4 years. Not available outside the classroom, criteria for all assignments is very vague, lectures are incredibly boring and she shows no passion for the course. Don't take this course with her as it will be a very big regret. She has made this course a waste of money.

It seems like most BBA students will end up with Connie as their prof at some point in their degree, which is unfortunate. Connie would frequently assign lengthy presentations and assignments that were not graded, but had to be done to a certain standard because they would be presented in front of your clients whom you are doing the project for.
The worst sfu prof. Don't take class with her for the sake of your own sanity.

Connie is a nice teacher and puts effort into finding great organizations for groups to work with during the semester-long project (great networking opportunity). Some assignments can be vague on Canvas, however, she goes into detail in class about what she expects, so make sure you pay attention.

You work on a group project all semester which is worth less than the Final Exam which makes no sense. Most of the lectures you just work on your project or she rambles forever. The concepts are not difficult but grading criteria is virtually non-existent and she grades very hard. She's nice for the most part but not the best prof.

This class was horrible. This woman is clearly very bitter about her life and uses “teaching” as an opportunity to be rude, condescending, and disrespectful towards students who are paying to be present. She rambles on about absolutely nothing related to the course and talks down to you. Clearly projecting her inner struggles. Quit teaching

Shes an entertaining lecturer who doesn't go over course content very well, all criteria's are vague. She can be rude and condescending, not a very sympathetic prof to say the least. Avoid her class if you can, sorry for those taking ops management.

This class is a complete disaster. She spends the entire time yelling,complaining and going on irrelevant, bitter rants about everything from students to businesses. She's rude, condescending, and unprofessional. Even her own TA isn't safe,she trashes him behind his back like it's nothing. There's zero teaching, zero learning, and 100% wasted time.

No clear grading criteria. Reverse lectures, which is fine. She rambles about a lot of nonsense during her lectures so I don't get the point of them. She's condescending and doesn't explain herself clearly. Essentially a self taught class with a grump lady rambling through it. Unfortunately it is a requirement for some concentrations.

If your looking for a class with zero grading criteria, a sassy & unhelpful prof this is the class for you. She doesn't do any teaching in class as she has a reverse class teaching style...  I don't mind except for the fact the time in class isn't used well. She designates work to her TA's who aren't upto date with her teachings (or lack thereof).

I liked how Connie would leave time for group discussions/project work & appreciate that she sits with teams individually to discuss any pinpoints. But, I didn't find the lectures helpful and her expectations for assignments were extremely unclear and at times comments left on assignments made it seem like she did not carefully review the details.

Doesn't really teach, and even states that herself. For an introductory project management class, she expects students to be able to read concepts and be able to understand them to apply for assignments due days after that topic's lecture. Also will "answer questions with a question," meaning expectations are very unclear.

Connie's teaching style reflects real life project management in many ways. First, it is unstructured. Second, it is more important to convince others you did a good job than doing a good job. And third, you don't really use the technical stuff. With this perspective, Connie prepares you for PM, but the course is tiring.

Connie makes BUS 361 feel like a 4 credit course. The group work itself requires about 8 hours a week of work and even more if you get stuck with a bad group. Her weekly assignments and readings take another 5-8 hours. I have had 4 credit courses that felt like a breeze compared to BUS 361. Connies unclear grading criteria does not help either.

Instructor Connie is a caring professor who believes students are geniuses (while sometimes lazy).

She comes with incredible industry experience and gives her students the opportunity to work with an actual business.

While her lectures are a little dry, her activities (e.g. the tower building game) and term-long project are phenomenal.

While I am sure that Connie is a good businesswoman, she is not a great lecturer. She constantly drones on and on about topics without any clear point or conclusion.

Also, if you have any difficulty paying attention in class (and especially if you have ADHD), DO NOT TAKE CONNIE. I am a fairly attentive student, and I found it a pain to focus.

Connie is very unorganized and gets confused about the deadlines she sets. All her assignments have very unclear criteria even after asking questions so get ready to lose marks for random things. She sets up her class in a way to simulate project management jobs which I appreciate but it wasn't executed well. Final did not reflect the class.

Connie's teaching styles made this course unenjoyable, useless, and difficult. She does not give instructions for assignments (even ones that are 20% of your grade), provides vague feedback with no meaning, and is disorganized. Lectures involved making paper airplanes and building spaghetti towers (irrelevant and did not contribute to my learning)
Connie didn't provide much support when it came to the assignment. If I could take this course again, I would choose a different professor.
I would say she really didn't teach anything. We made paper airplanes during class... this class was a waste of time. I'd say take this class with someone else if possible.

Gives lots of class time to finish assignments. Assignments can be a bit unclear at times, but during lecture she gives a lot of tips so its good to come to class. She gave really good feedback on how to correct mistakes. Someone said she was sarcastic, and I agree but she's never rude. People just want a reason to hate and justify their low mark.

I am surprised to see Connie's rating to be this low. Connie is very direct with her feedback which can come across as rude sometimes, but she knows her stuff and is an expert in project management. Lectures can go on tangents and be unclear from time to time, but she is a great and approachable prof in general. Choose your group members wisely!

Connie Liu is not fit to teach project management. She routinely assigns major assignments with no grading criteria whatsoever. That aside, even despite having no real rubric for grading for most assignments, she also gives very rude, often sarcastic, and unclear feedback.

Connie was overall a good professor. Sure she is not clear with the grading criteria or what is required for each assignment but she is willing to help out if you are willing to ask her questions. Her teaching style is more to prepare you for a real job in PM vs an academic-focused style. As long as you adapt to her style you will be fine.
Grading was very late and final exam was poorly written. Id advise taking this course with a different professor.

Daniel is a great professor, but even a better human being. You can tell that he genuinely loves project management. His classes are truly inspirational and he is amazing at teaching the concepts. His final was a little bit difficult as it focused on tiny details rather than the big picture so make sure you study all the little details.

Throughout my 4 years at SFU, I have to say Daniel is the best professor I have ever had. His teaching style shows his dedication and love for his craft, and more importantly, he truly cares about his students. Although the class is concept heavy and somewhat challenging, Daniel makes sure the class understands the ideology before moving on.

Amazing professor. If you pay attention during lectures and study the slides, you are golden for the exam. The textbook is quite lengthy, but not too important. However, this course is very heavy - a big group project and exam. He is super accessible though and super understanding. Overall, an amazing professor and I would highly recommend him!

Great Professor if you want to go into project management or get CAPM/PMP designations. Things he taught helped tremendously in perparing for my CAPM exam, and in my experience as a Jr. Project Manager. The negative ratings seem to be from students who had to take this calss to meet concentration requirements, but I found this class very valuable.

Daniel gave us his phone number on the first day of class and told us to call him at any time - and he meant it! The most accessible prof I have ever had. He was very inspiring and we had many great conversations inside and outside the "classroom" (it was online). The course itself is very group project heavy but he lets you make your own teams.

Daniel was an amazing prof!! He went out of his way to be super available 24/7 for us to talk to him almost every week. He's super knowledgeable in project management because it's his career!! He was always super encouraging and although this course was a lot of work, it was worth it in the end! Just ask for help when you need it! :)

I'm not sure why Daniel has so many bad reviews - he's a great prof. I took BUS361 with him this summer, and he taught it the right way. Yes, it was a lot of work, but project management isn't supposed to be easy! Challenging content and competitiveness is expected, but he makes it a hands-on exp.; the book makes sense because you're applying it.

Professor Daniel truly knows a lot about project management as he has the added bonus of actually working as a project manager. He does a good job of providing real-life project management examples in class and was super helpful when it came to executing our own chosen group project. Super caring professor and loves when you participate! :)

I really enjoyed Daniels' Project Management class, he cares about his students and wants to see them succeed. Unlike many profs, he actually practices what he teaches and offers real-life examples and experiences to illustrate class topics. The group project was a lot of fun where each team was tasked with creating and executing a real project.

BUS 361 is a very group-project intensive course with deliverables almost on a weekly basis. Therefore, it is very crucial that you have a high functioning group. Daniel, as an instructor, did an excellent job at solving any group conflicts. He is very easily accessible, even outside of class and always provides thorough feedback on your work.

He's a solid choice of a prof for BUS 361. I wouldn't say that he's one of the best/worst profs at SFU, but he's just avg. For this course, there's a lot of group work. Daniel is extremely helpful with feedback as long as you set a meeting with him. He's very accessible with meeting times, and he genuinely wants you to succeed in his class.

Horrible terrible professor. Avoid at all costs. Loves to go over time in our 6:30 to 9:30 classes. Marking is not standardized whatsoever. The week before the midterm we built a boat. Discourages questions by shutting people down. Over the weeks nobody would participate anymore; then he starts complaining that nobody participates. Has tedx talk.

Terribly frustrating class. Given no time for any of the assignments, unclear instructions, and way too many deliverables. Hard to listen about project management when the professor cannot even manage a class. Funny guy though.

Daniel doesn't give you enough time to complete projects. The worst moment was when everyone was only given 3 days to complete the final paper worth 20% of your grade. There is also much more work required for this class than there should be for a 3 credit class. Daniel also constantly showed up late to class and kept us in the lecture late.
Doesn't post assignments till last minute, often late to lectures, and doesn't respect student's time

Started off rough, but Jan became a lot more friendly and encouraging as the course went on. Half of his final was pulled from textbook sample questions, but overall the grading was easygoing, and the atmosphere in his classroom was engaging. Pretty good / 10

I really enjoyed this class and found it useful as the content is applicable to all courses and careers. Jan was very knowledgeable and kept the class engaged. We get to choose our own project to carry through. Which means the outcome is as good as the work you put in. I don't know what happened last semester but marking and feedback was on time.

Worst class I've ever taken. Jan didn't teach anything useful - the textbook did a better job (and the textbook sucks). He hasn't returned ANY marking. Didn't reply to a single one of my emails this term. Irresponsible and doesn't care about students, yet pretends to be a nice guy. Sucked up to us right before the course evaluations. Greasy!

Jan is fantastic guy, has a wealth of knowledge about project management, but is awful at creating structure and providing feedback. Didn't receive any marks back for any of the assignments. Provided a template for the final project but told us not to follow it. Overall a valuable course but poorly evaluated

Knowledgeable, but not accessible for guidance on projects, even thru email. He's too busy with other work. Neither him nor his TA holds office hrs. No documented feedback so far, hard to tell where we're at. Verbal feedback was "looks ok". Templates provided, if any, are not helpful or complete. Hasn't uploaded class slides for the past 3 weeks.

I didn't learn anything, despite REALLY wanting to. No tools/guidance aside from prof opinionated PM concepts. Jan clearly didn't care about this course, student learning or enthusiasm. Quizzes & finals were jokes (all MC). NO marking was returned, NO feedback, NO value. Go take a weekend online PM course, and join an SFU club. Worst course ever.

Jan was an amazing teacher and very encouraging of after-lecture beers! No midterm, the project really depends on your team and how original it is (mine got an A), the final is half essay qs (we got to pick 4/7 to answer) and half multiple choice with a bonus q. The final project is BIG so start early! Easy A if you keep up w/readings
The BEST professor ever. Highly recommend him.

Course load is not heavy. Jan is friendly and very easy to talk to, but not always accessible. Material is a little dry; in-class discussions are interesting. Online quizzes and exams almost solely based on textbook. Project, however, doesn't really use textbook.
Nice guy but not very accessible when it comes to e-mails; he rarely ever responds.  Also difficult to get have a lot of time with him during group work.

Definitely take Project Management with Jan. The projects are fairly interesting without being too much work and the lectures have a lot of interaction so that students can stay awake. MC is a bit tricky on the midterm. But overall the grading is very fair and skewed on the high side.

Nice guy, very easy going...just don't show up late for his classes...he hates that!! He ties in the real world to his lectures, after all it is a project management course. I would have to say that the only negative thing is that assignments were slow to get marked.
He's a nice guy but he is too picky in general. very detail oriented that it becomes annoying. too many assignments for the course

the class wasn't too bad. Pretty easy.His MT are easy If you read the textbook and study his notes. INteresting class, it relates to life and you actually learn how to apply this class in the real world, so that's good. I highly recommend this class.

Jan relies on webCT too much. It's funny how he lectures about project management and yet his course is so unorganized and unreliable. Sometimes he takes a month to reply emails, literally. Midterm is fair though.
Good prof, interested in project mgmt and applies real life experiences.
